reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central element of the essay: the claim that (conditional on survival and without strong optimization) the set of mostly-great futures is narrow because many plausible ‘single flaws’ can wipe out most attainable value, and because evaluation is benchmarked to a very high “best feasible” ceiling. If a broad satisficing plateau existed, or if the >50% framing were mostly an artifact of an extreme ceiling, that would substantially undercut the “no easy eutopia” conclusion.

However, the critique’s refutation is only moderate. It mostly asserts (rather than demonstrates) that high-value plateaus are likely, and it doesn’t engage the essay’s specific mechanisms for narrowness (multiplicative-factor model; fussy-vs-easygoing analysis across bounded/unbounded value functions; fat-tailed value-efficiency; and the explicit attempt to define “best feasible” as a high percentile of a probability distribution rather than a literal cosmic maximum). The point about action-relevance/marginal tractability is more of a priority-shift than a direct rebuttal of the essay’s descriptive claim about how much value is typically lost.

Correctness is mixed: it is plausible that benchmark-relative thresholds can make “losing most value” look too easy, but the critique somewhat mischaracterizes the paper as conflating ‘hard to guarantee’ with ‘hard to achieve most value’ given the paper’s explicit probabilistic framing. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Conflating hard-to-guarantee with hard-to-achieve most value
